Quick, mobile news: live-streaming video from an iPhone 4

by Noel Cody on November 18, 2010 · 9271 commenthttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F2010%2F11%2F18%2Fquick-mobile-news%2FQuick%2C+mobile+news%3A+live-streaming+video+from+an+iPhone+42010-11-18+22%3A55%3A51Noel+Codyhttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F%3Fp%3D927

in iPhone,Social media,Twitter

Live-streaming video isn’t new. Mobile technology isn’t new. But the ability to stream video in real-time from a smartphone has just now become widely available, and  we tried it for the first time this morning at reesenews.org.

We used an iPhone 4 to stream live video from the UNC-Chapel Hill Board of Trustees meeting at the Carolina Inn. While the board-members discussed a tuition increase and UNC-CH’s recent NCAA football investigation, I stood to the side of the room and shot video on the tiny device, surrounded by tripods and large news cameras from other local news organizations.

It was a strange experience — only a green light in the corner of the screen let me know I was streaming live. But the video ran from the phone, through a web service called Qik and onto a page at reesenews.org — and people watched. In about two hours, we received 93 views total, with an average of 9.19 minutes spent per view.

We did hit some snags.

At first, we tried to rely on the phone’s 3G connection, but the connection wasn’t strong enough and the video stream was choppy. We fell back on  the Carolina Inn’s wifi connection, but the connection was weak in some places in the room, and we had to move around before we found a spot with a strong signal. Next time, we’ll scout the location out beforehand.

While I filmed, Reese Felts Digital News Project multimedia reporter Rebecca Seawell live-tweeted from our Twitter account. This wasn’t the original plan — at first, Becca was going to simply stream live video. But when I went to troubleshoot connectivity issues, we decided that I should shoot while she typed.

Turns out the combination worked well – when the wifi signal became weak and the video stream went down, our audience could switch over to Twitter to continue to receive information. The live-tweets also allowed our audience to look back at information and quotes from earlier on in the meeting. Finally, we used the opportunity to cross-promote; we notified the live-stream viewers of our live-tweeting, and our Twitter followers of the live-stream. The combination of live text and live video worked well, and it’s something we’ll do again in the future, if possible.

The other news organizations in the room emerged with higher-quality video, no doubt about it.

But the iPhone 4 is a new tool for a new form of live, engaging news coverage.

We’re brainstorming new ways to use these mobile tool, and mobile live video is full of potential.

As we continue to seek new ways to bring news to the community and to engage our audience, we’ll aim to use the iPhone4 Qik video in new ways.

Tagged as: Board of Trustees, iPhone 4, UNC-Chapel Hill

{ 1 comment… read it below or add one }

1 reesedn November 19, 2010 at 2:14 pm

I'm really excited the students pulled this off. Really cool. Very innovative use of the iPhone.

Yes, the snags are generally due to bandwidth issues. Even if you were to have tested the room prior, no one can predict how quickly multiplying mobile handsets in the room or with passing motorists and pedestrians could affect the connection to the AT&T tower in the area.

Remember, a tower can only handle so many concurrent connections. For that reason, the more individuals accessing that tower, the better the chance the 3g connection, while fast, would drop packets and affect the mobile web cast.

Switching over to wi-fi was a great second choice. That enabled the students to use a more reliable connection. But, even then, you still have to worry about concurrent users in the room.

The only way you could get reliable bandwidth out of the room, is have a hard wired ethernet connection. But the goal was not to use the tried and true. It was to use the iPhone 4 as a vehicle to capture and distribute a live event over the reesenews web site.

This shows how important it is for multimedia platform journalists to understand the bandwidth limitations of their equipment and working environment, as well as the options to quickly resolve them.

Without any formal training, Noel Cody and Rebecca Seawell improvised and successfully executed a mobile web cast using the iPhone 4. They gave reesnews and Dean Folkerts something very cool to talk about!
